Jon  has been a scenic carpenter, production electrician, Off-Broadway TD and ATD in  New York for over twenty years. Jon received his BFA in Design/Illustration  from Marywood College. Jon co-teaches the first year scenery  stagecraft class.        Ella Bromblin   Budget Director. After years of studying mathematics at Odessa  University in Ukraine, Ella decided to find herself closer to the arts and  began working as a budget director at TSOA.   Ella also takes photos of all the Graduate Acting / Dance / Design  productions. Ella has been working at  NYU for over 25 years.          Ellie Bye   Props Master. During her first week living in NYC, Ellie  achieved a life long dream: dressing the Bergdorf Goodman and Van Cleef &  Arpel windows for Fashion's Night Out. Ellie has worked in the prop departments  at Williamstown Theatre Festival, The Santa Fe Opera, The Public Theater, and  The Bucks County Playhouse. Her artisan work has been seen at venues like  Manhattan Theater Club, New World Stages, and The Paper Mill Playhouse. TV  credits include MTV and Saturday Night Live. Ellie  co-teaches the first year scenery stagecraft class. BFA  Theatrical Production and Set Design from Pennsylvania State University.           Daun Fallon   Costume Shop Manager.   After receiving a BA in Costume Design from the University of California,  Santa Barbara, Daun spent 10 years working as a draper for several theaters  including the Denver Center and the Santa Fe Opera. Daun also spent more  than a decade heading the design department at a NYC based doll company  (creating miniature costumes) before returning to the theatre. Daun co-teaches  the costume stagecraft class with Maggie Raywood.          David Fry Charge Scenic Artist.  David has been the scenic artist at the University of Cincinnati CCM and the  Opera Theatre of Lucca, Italy, as well as “Playing With Fire” the national  touring exhibition of Julie Taymor’s designs. David was the 2002 USITT Exekiel  Award of Distinction recipient for Scenic Craft, and his work has been featured  on the cover of Stage Directions trade magazine. He has a BFA from the  University of Cincinnati and is an accomplished exhibited oil painter.   Kate Gibson Producing Coordinator. Most recently Kate has coordinated hundreds of productions and events for The Clarice Smith Performing Arts Center at the University of Maryland, College Park. She is also the founding Production Manager for the Charm City Fringe Festival in her native Baltimore. A member of Actors' Equity Association, Kate has dozens of management and performance credits spanning New York, Regional Theatre, and National/International Tours. B.Mus. Shenandoah Conservatory in Music and Theatre, M.A. NYU/Steinhardt in Musical Theatre Performance.      Chris Girard   Master Carpenter. After receiving his MA in Fine Art and Art History from the Sorbonne, Paris, Chris moved from  France to the US. He began working at NYU in 2003 as a freelance carpenter, scenic painter, and electrician. Following 2 years working as a gallery guide  at the Guggenheim, Chris became the Master Carpenter at NYU. In addition, he has worked in the design and building of window displays for brands such as Versace, Dolce & Gabbana,  and Bloomingdales.       Erik Grathwohl Supervisor of Second Year Production. Erik has been a scenic designer, dramaturg, scenic  carpenter, production electrician, and Off-Broadway TD and ATD in New York  for seven years. He also worked for two years as a lighting designer for an NJ-based national production company. Erik received his BFA in Scenic and  Technical production from Carnegie Mellon, and his MFA in Dramaturgy from Columbia University. Erik co-teaches the first year scenery stagecraft class.        Megan Dawson Jaffe   First Hand/Stitcher. Megan received her MFA in Costume Construction from Boston University in 2003, and promptly moved to  New York. Before coming to NYU, she worked at Carelli Costumes on various Broadway and off-Broadway productions. Other technical credits include The  Court Theatre at the University of Chicago, American Players Theatre, and Glimmerglass Opera. Megan's life outside of NYU includes freelance projects  that range from haunted houses to drag queens to ecclesiastic wear.          Ann Mathews Director of Production.   Ann has supervised several hundred graduate productions at TSOA. She is a recipient of the NYU Distinguished  Administrator of the Year award. Ann has worked in theatres from Alaska to  Alabama, including such venues as the Arena Stage, Yale Repertory Theatre,  Playwrights Horizon, and the Intiman, Seattle Rep and Empty Space theatres in  Seattle. She holds a BA in Theatre from the University of Washington and an MA  in Religion from the Claremont School of Theology.          Margaret Raywood Costume Director. Please click above to see her faculty biography.          Katherine Takacs   Associate Technical Director. Katie graduated from  the University of Arizona with her BFA in Technical Theater, emphasis in Technical  Direction and Scene Design in 2008. She worked at Trinity Repertory Company as  a carpenter and welder for two years, and was the Technical Director for the  Brown/Trinity Rep MFA Program. Katie was the Technical Director at Rattlestick  Playwrights' Theatre, working on such productions as underneathmybed, The  Hallway Trilogy, and Asuncion, amongst many others. She also worked  as a freelance carpenter at various Off - Broadway theaters, before beginning her  association with Theatrical Production.   Katie co-teaches the first year scenery stagecraft class.          Mike Voytko   Lighting and Sound Supervisor.  Previous work includes: Resident Lighting Designer, Boheme Opera NJ; Lighting  Coordinator, Opera Co. of Philadelphia; Master Electrician, Wilma Theater and  Philadelphia Theatre Co.; Assistant Master Electrician, Williamstown Theatre  Festival.        Lydia Witt   Stitcher/Wardrobe. New Studio On Broadway: Music Theatre: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Drama Drama News & Events Box Office About The Program How To Apply Faculty Administration Student Center Production Resource Office Production Archive High School Programs Summer in Drama Alumni FAQ  home > Drama        New Studio On Broadway: Music Theatre  New Studio integrates foundational acting training in vocal and physical techniques by drawing upon both the repertoire of the American musical and the classical acting canon to hone the actors’ instrument in all aspects of both disciplines. The course of study emphasizes exposure to new work, world music, and contemporary, global, diverse performance forms.  Teaching students the power and value of the ensemble, the young practitioners of music theatre will have their core acting, speech and movement classes together. The New Studio stresses a unified training in all skill areas essential to the performer’s craft. This will equip young artists to meet the fluid demands of a progressive, diverse and global stage.  New Studio focuses on the union of rigorous physical and vocal training always connected to the manifestation of character, the clear playing of a dramatic action, and the illumination of ideas within the text, as these are the fundamentals of the actor’s process. Rather than embracing and espousing a single methodology or approach, classes offer practical application of competencies required for an actor to develop a dynamic versatility that will enable them to fluidly move through a range of performance idioms. Our objective is to provide the actor with the requisite skill set necessary to sustain a lifelong career as a professional actor, at play with global audiences onstage, in the musical theatre, in the new technologies and in whatever lies beyond. Master artist/teachers working in the field at a national and international level will teach all courses. Lawrence Fellowship    Playbill Attends The Fix (Photo Slideshow Here)       Selected Events       Summer Music Theatre Workshop       Featured Students       Read about our current students              The Steinhardt School's program in Vocal Performance offers music-based training for a career in music theatre performance. Our curriculum is designed for the serious young musician who is seeking a program that fully integrates the study of voice with the study of acting. We are committed to the traditions of classically-based vocal training while at the same time allowing students to explore the demanding repertoire that is expected of professional singers in today's ever-expanding world of music theatre performance.    In addition to voice, acting and dance, as well as courses in music theatre repertoire and history, the core of our program's music theatre specialization training takes place through an intensive series of music theatre workshops. These workshops explore such critical areas as movement, speech, diction, song study, scene study, audition skills, and business skills - the essential "tools of the trade" that a young artist needs in order to pursue a professional career.    In addition to the work in classrooms and studios, the program offers performance opportunities in fully-staged productions under the guidance of professional directors, choreographers, conductors, musical directors, and designers. Our guest artists and faculty are drawn from New York's vibrant community of professional artists who count Broadway, off-Broadway, regional theatre and national tours among their credits.    Students specializing in Music Theatre make their New York "debut" in their final semester as they are presented to New York's agents, casting directors, directors, and producers in their graduation showcase - a revue designed to feature the work of each student and help them make their first professional contacts in the industry.    The Department's acclaimed programs of study in Music Business (B.M., M.A.), Music Technology (B.M., M.M., Ph.D.), Jazz (B.M., M.M., Ph.D.), Music Composition (B.M., M.M., Ph.D.), and Music Education (B.M., M.A., Ph.D.) provide a rich and valuable array of elective courses for music performance majors that prepare them for an ever-changing music industry and musical climate. Undergraduate and graduate students also benefit from the extraordinary opportunities available through the diverse offerings of a major university in the cultural capital of the world, New York City.
